Literature Review: Biological phenotyping in sepsis and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has emerged as a crucial approach to overcome the heterogeneity in these clinical conditions. The increasing availability of high-throughput biological data ('omics') and computational power has enabled researchers to develop and apply phenotyping schemas to sepsis and ARDS. Phenotyping aims to identify homogenous subgroups within a heterogenous population using a multitude of data, which can lead to the development of targeted therapies (1). In sepsis, phenotyping has been used to identify subphenotypes such as septic shock and sepsis-induced organ dysfunction (2). Similarly, in ARDS, phenotyping has been applied to identify subphenotypes such as diffuse alveolar damage and acute respiratory failure (3). These subphenotypes can be used to develop personalized treatment strategies and improve patient outcomes (4). However, the translation of phenotyping findings to bedside clinical decision-making tools is challenging due to the complexity of the data and the need for standardization (5). One of the key challenges is the development of a common language and framework for phenotyping, which can facilitate the comparison of data across different studies and institutions (6). To address this challenge, researchers have proposed the use of standardized phenotyping schemas such as the Sepsis-3 definition and the ARDS Network definition (7, 8). These schemas provide a common framework for phenotyping and can help to standardize the collection and analysis of data. Despite the challenges, biological phenotyping has the potential to revolutionize the treatment of sepsis and ARDS by enabling the development of targeted therapies and personalized treatment strategies. Further research is needed to fully realize the potential of phenotyping in these clinical conditions.
